textAfterTable: On March 2002, a planned pregnancy occurred after dexamethasone substitution for alpha-methyldopa 500 mg tid. Pregnancy was uneventful with normal blood pressure levels and no pre-eclampsia or eclampsia. A boy was born with normal weight and normal vitality at 5 and 10 min. Phallopian tubes were ligated at the time and dexamethasone was again resumed 1.0 mg, at bedtime every other day.  On August 2005, the patient now aged 37 was again admitted to the Endocrine Department because of acute gastroenteritis with serious hypokalemia (1.8 mEq/L). The patient denied missing any drug schedule and she was not hypertensive. There was no fever and the stools were without blood, mucus or pus. C-Reactive protein was negative. Again high serum aldosterone levels (280 pg/mL) and low renin levels (0.7 μU/mL) were measured. Three days later after correction of the clinical condition and serum potassium the patient was discharged and previous medication was resumed.  Again for 2 years, evolution was uneventful with normal blood pressure levels and normal serum potassium, and no relevant side effects.  Since 2008, blood pressure levels began to increase despite drug treatment and spironolactone 100 mg/day and later bisoprolol 5 mg/day were added.
